description: Contemporary accounting and corporate financial reporting. Preparation, interpretation, and analysis of the earnings statement; the statement of financial position; and the statement of cash flows. 1 Credit. Tuition: $2,750. Session A: May 31 - July 2.
title: Financial Accounting
subject: ACCT

description: Introduction to the analysis of film and the study of black popular culture through Spike Lee's films. Close textual analysis of Lee's styles, sources, creative dilemmas, and collaborations. Topics include feminism and the erotic, sex/sexuality/gender, concepts of black leadership, cinematic reflexivity, early film history, race and racism, stereotypes, auteur theory, and questions of audience and authenticity.  1 Credit. Tuition: $2750. Session A: May 31 - July 2.
title: Spike Lee
subject: AFAM

description: The development of African American political activism and political theory from 1960 to 1972, with a focus on student movements. Agitation for civil rights and social equality traced through the history and political agendas of the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee and the Black Panther Party. How key members of these organizations created policies and platforms that were meant to empower people of African descent in a way that the civil rights movement did not. 1 Credit. Tuition: $2,750. Session A: May 31 - July 2.
title: African American Student Activism in the 1960s
subject: AFAM

description: The development of African American fiction over the last century. African American literature's distinctive characteristics and its relation to the idea of a national literature. Literary representations of race, space, migration, and violence; historical circumstances that inform these representations. Prerequisite: some experience with college-level literary analysis. 1 Credit. Tuition: $2,750. Session A: May 31 - July 2.
title: Modern African American Fiction
subject: AFAM

description: Examination of the social, cultural, and political phenomenon known as the Harlem Renaissance. Topics include resistance to oppression, autonomy, the intersection between culture and politics, and the place of the Harlem Renaissance within the larger struggle for equality. Readings from both primary and secondary sources. 1 Credit. Tuition: $2750. Session B: July 5 - August 6.
title: New Negro Arts and Politics
subject: AFAM

description: Responses by law enforcement and the wider criminal justice system to political and moral imperatives advanced under the banner of diversity and multiculturalism. Introduction to relevant criminological and sociological concepts, theories, and debates. The relationship between social identity and perceptions of criminality. Contemporary social issues such as racial profiling, disproportionate punishment, unequal justice, and terrorism. 1 Credit. Tuition: $2,750. Session B: July 5 - August 6.
title: Multiculturalism and the Ordered Society
subject: AFAM

description: Offered in New Haven; Mbabane, Swaziland; and Durban, South Africa. This interdisciplinary course introduces students to major issues of the HIV/AIDS pandemic in southern Africa through the perspective of community-engaged theatrical practice. Students will actively engage ideas encountered in our first week of intensive classroom work, held in New Haven, through theater workshops with local artists in Mbabane, Swaziland and Cape Town, South Africa. Two-week collaborations with theater companies in Swaziland and South Africa will amplify and deepen our classroom study of theater as a mode of social and political intervention and of major topics on the HIV/AIDS pandemic. Through experiences in the classroom and in the field, students will arrive at deeply informed perspectives on the AIDS pandemic in southern Africa and will gain an activated understanding of the issues in public health, as well as the possibilities for theatrical interventions. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Swaziland and South Africa, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: March 1. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 2 Credits. Tuition $5,300. Course dates: May 31 - July 9.
short_title: Arts and Public Health in Act...
title: Arts and Public Health in Action: Study of HIV/AIDS in Swaziland and South Africa
subject: AFST

description: Offered in Mombasa, Kenya. Survey of the modern history of East Africa, with a focus on health, environment, and society. The rise of Swahili language and culture; slavery and plantation agriculture; colonial regimes, medical discourse, and environmental degradation; agrarian protest and nationalist mobilization; conservation ethics and national parks; female genital cutting; HIV/AIDS. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Mombasa, costs of room and board in Mombasa, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: April 1. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 2 Credits. Yale students may petition for one HU area credit. Tuition: $5,300. Session B: June 28 - August 7.
title: History of East Africa
subject: AFST

description: A survey of American literature and culture in the first half of the twentieth century. Works by Henry James, Willa Cather, Ernest Hemingway, F. Scott Fitzgerald, William Faulkner, T.S. Eliot, Ezra Pound, Wallace Stevens, William Carlos Williams, Nella Larsen, Langston Hughes, and Gertrude Stein. Please see online syllabus for readings for the first day of class. 1 Credit. Tuition: $2750. Session B: July 5 - August 6.
title: Modern American Literature, 1900-1950
subject: AMST

description: American literature after 1950, focusing on novels by Ralph Ellison, Kurt Vonnegut, Toni Morrison, Maxine Hong Kingston, Sandra Cisneros, Philip Roth and Jhumpa Lahiri. Extra readings will include short pieces by James Baldwin, Saul Bellow, John Updike, Don DeLillo, and Amy Tan, as well as articles touching on censorship and the politics of canon formation. We will also consider the portrayals of race, class, ethnicity, religion, trauma, citizenship and sexuality in these works, and the ways in which these authors conceptualize American identity. 1 Credit. Tuition $2,750. Session A: May 31 - July 2.
title: Contemporary American Literature
subject: AMST

description: Key topics in the history of New England since the end of the Civil War. Changing social, economic, and political realities; shifting conceptions of regional identity promoted by inhabitants and outsiders. Factors that have made New England at once prototypical and atypical within the United States amidst broader transformations in American society. Topics include immigration and migration, industrialization and deindustrialization, agricultural decline and tourism, urban renewal, defense spending and high technology, racial and ethnic conflict, environmental movements, gay rights, and professional sports. 1 Credit. Tuition $2,750. Session B: July 5 - August 6.
title: New England: Region and Identity, 1865-present
subject: AMST

description: Responses by law enforcement and the wider criminal justice system to political and moral imperatives advanced under the banner of diversity and multiculturalism. Introduction to relevant criminological and sociological concepts, theories, and debates. The relationship between social identity and perceptions of criminality. Contemporary social issues such as racial profiling, disproportionate punishment, unequal justice, and terrorism. 1 Credit. Tuition: $2,750. Session B: July 5 - August 6.
title: Multiculturalism and the Ordered Society
subject: AMST

description: A survey of the histories of both the Hollywood novel and films about Hollywood. Examination of the ways in which these two genres portray "the dream factory" - its past, its present, and its future - as well as the way they interact. Books include Harry Leon Wilson's Merton at the Movies, Horace McCoy's They Shoot Horses, Don't They? and I Should Have Stayed Home, F. Scott Fitzgerald's The Last Tycoon, Budd Schulberg's What Makes Sammy Run, and Gore Vidal's Myra Breckenridge. Films include What Price Hollywood? A Star Is Born, Sunset Boulevard, In a Lonely Place, The Star, and The Player. 1 Credit. Tuition: $2750. Session A: May 31 - July 2.
short_title: The Hollywood Novel and the H...
title: The Hollywood Novel and the Hollywood Movie
subject: AMST

description: The rise of the idea of leisure within American society, and the particular forms that idea has taken. We will consider the amateur sports and the recreational habits that won popularity in the U.S. from the end of the nineteenth through the late twentieth centuries. We will also evaluate the place of professional sports from a legal and business perspective. 1 Credit. Tuition: $2750. Session B: July 5 - August 6.
title: Sports, Leisure, and Recreation in American Culture, 1880-1980
subject: AMST

description: An introductory course on American images of Asia and Asian America in twentieth-century literature and cinema. The extent to which the Asia that emerges in literary and visual culture was a product not only of powerful Euro-American visions of Asian "others," but also of dialogic re-imaginations of Asia created by Asian Americans themselves. 1 Credit. Tuition: $2750. Session A: May 31 - July 2.
short_title: East Asia in US Literature an...
title: East Asia in US Literature and Film
subject: AMST

description: This course will examine the representation and documentation of American history on film and digital video, through the close analysis of a series of narrative fiction features depicting a wide variety of historical periods and major events in the nation's history. Topics will include Contact, the Civil War and Reconstruction, the Great Depression, World War II, the Cold War, Watergate and September 11th. This course seeks to expand its students' knowledge of the history of American film, culture and society, and to encourage its students to think analytically about how movies express historical content. In-class screenings will include Scarface, Gone with the Wind, The Outlaw Josey Wales, Gangs of New York, The New World, United 93 and Inglourious Basterds. 1 Credit. Tuition $2,750. Session B: July 5 - August 6.
title: Film, Video, and American History
subject: AMST

description: An introduction to the central ideas, methods, and debates that make up the anthropological study of human thought and behavior. Survey of dynamic ways of life in many different societies; outline of the ways anthropologists have tried to understand societies. Hands-on ethnographic research provides insight into how cultural anthropologists do what they do, what problems they encounter and what tools and techniques they use for research and analysis. Film screenings meet W 8-10pm. 1 Credit. Tuition: $2750. Session B: July 5 - August 6.
title: Introduction to Cultural Anthropology
subject: ANTH

description: Introduction to human and primate evolution, primate behavior, and human biology. Topics include a review of principles of evolutionary and population biology, the evolution of primates and people, and current thinking about the evolution of human behavior. 1 Credit. Tuition: $2750. Session A: May 31 - July 2.
title: Introduction to Biological Anthropology
subject: ANTH

description: The prehistory of Mesopotamia, Egypt, and the Indus Valley, with a focus on important archaeological discoveries. Introduction to the basics of archaeological method and theory. Topics include human origins, the origins of agriculture, and the development of complex societies. Two field trips are planned. One will be a visit to a Connecticut archaeological excavation to better understand the basics of archaeological method and theory. The other will be a visit to the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York City to see exhibits on cultures discussed in class. 1 Credit. Tuition: $2750. Session A: May 31 - July 2.
title: Great Discoveries in Old World Archaeology
subject: ANTH

description: Hands-on introduction to forensic anthropology, using laboratory training, lectures, and case studies. Introduction to basic skeletal anatomy and to the use of recovered skeletal materials to assess a deceased individual's age, sex, height, ancestry, time of death, bone trauma, and disease. Additional topics include techniques for recovering human skeletal remains, reconstruction of faces, genetic identification, and medicolegal contexts of forensic anthropology. 1 Credit. Tuition: $2750. Session A: May 31 - July 2.
title: Forensic Anthropology
subject: ANTH

description: The archaeology of Mesopotamia, Egypt, and the Indus Valley from early agriculture to class formation and the early cities and empires. How did these societies develop and why did they collapse? Earliest epics and contemporary ideologies, including the Bushes in Baghdad, examined in literature and film. Readings in translation. 1 Credit. Tuition: $2750. Session A: May 31 - July 2.
short_title: The Genesis and Collapse of O...
title: The Genesis and Collapse of Old World Civilizations
subject: ANTH

description: Offered in Bocas del Toro, Panama. A study of the evolutionary biology and behavior of primates, focusing on the techniques of field observation and data collection in a tropical environment. Behavioral sampling, habitat measures, and statistical analyses are used to teach effective hypothesis development, testing, and report writing and presentation. Evaluation of the behavior of primates, our closest relatives, in the wild in order to gain insight into behavioral ecology, adaptation, and evolution. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Panama, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: April 1. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 2 Credits. Tuition $5,300. Course dates: May 15 - June 11.
title: Field Course in Primate Ecology and Behavior
subject: ANTH

description: Offered in Tokyo, Japan. Animation (anime) and graphic novels (manga) in twentieth-century Japan. Focus on the social and historical context of the production and consumption of manga and anime. Visits to sites mentioned in numerous works, fan conventions, and animation and manga production studios and museums. No knowledge of Japanese required. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Japan, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: April 1. Enrollment limited. For more information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 Credit. Tuition $2,750. Course Dates: May 29 - July 3.
title: Anime and Manga
subject: ANTH

description: Offered in Mumbai, India. Critical introduction to contemporary Indian politics, society, culture, and religion through immersive study in Mumbai. Topics include urbanization, poverty, migration, housing, communal violence, caste segregation, class ghettoization, and popular culture. Must be taken in conjunction with SAST S364. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from India, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: April 1. Enrollment limited. For more information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 Credit. Tuition $2,650. Session A: May 31 - July 2.
title: Bombay: City, Society and Culture
subject: ANTH

description: Seminar that examines the science behind selected advances in modern technology. Focus on the scientific and contextual basis of each advance, as well as the technology's resulting impact on society. Student groups present case studies, with topics developed by the participants in collaboration with the instructor. Intended for non-science majors. 1 Credit. Tuition: $2750. Session B: July 5 - August 6.
title: Science of Modern Technology
subject: APHY

description: Seminar which covers the technology, use, and impact of energy on the environment, climate, security, and the economy. Emphasis on what drives people's choices and the effects of those choices. Prerequisite: a background in high school physics, chemistry, and mathematics. 1 Credit. Tuition: $2750. Session A: May 31 - July 2.
title: Energy, Technology and Society
subject: APHY

description: Development of a basic knowledge of Modern Standard Arabic through a comprehensive and integrated method emphasizing reading, writing, speaking, comprehension, grammar, and vocabulary acquisition. Credit only on completion of ARBC S120. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition: $2,750. Session A: May 31 - July 2.

Intensive review of grammar; readings from contemporary and classical Arab authors with emphasis on serial reading of unvoweled Arabic texts, prose composition, and formal conversation. Must be taken in conjunction with ARBC S140. Prerequisite: ARBC 120 or equivalent. Application deadline: April 1. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $2,750. Course dates: May 31 - June 25.
title: Intermediate Modern Standard Arabic I
subject: ARBC

Readings from the Qur'an, Islamic theology, literature, history, philosophy, and the sciences by Arabic writing Muslim, Jewish, and Christian authors. Prerequisite: ARBC 120b or permission of instructor. 1 Credit. Tuition: $2750. Session A: May 31 - July 2.

description: Offered in Beijing, China. The Chinese house as the fundamental module of pre-1949 Chinese architecture and urbanism. Introduction to the programmatic, situational, and tectonic range of the courtyard house type. The elasticity and persistence of this type explored in three radically different sites: a central Beijing hutong siheyuan, an Anhui village, and the Forbidden City. Travel to sites in China, using surveying, analysis, and design exercises to gain an understanding of each location. Joint studio with Tsinghua University's School of Architecture. Must be taken in conjunction with ARCH S241. Prerequisite: an introductory course in architecture or drawing. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Beijing, room and board costs in China, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: April 1. Enrollment limited. For more information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 Credit. Tuition $2,650. Course dates: May 15 - July 3.
title: The Chinese House from Courtyard to City
subject: ARCH

description: Offered in Beijing, China. Themes in the history and theory of the Chinese built environment explored in relation to the typology of the Chinese house. Introduction to the history, culture, and evolution of Chinese architecture, gardens, and urbanism. The specific context of each project site examined through close readings and invited lectures. Must be taken in conjunction with ARCH S240. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Beijing, room and board costs in China, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: April 1. Enrollment limited. For more information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 Credit. Tuition $2,650. Course dates: May 15 - July 3.

description: An introduction to drawing, emphasizing pictorial syntax and the articulation of space. Class work is based on observational study. Assigned projects address fundamental technical and conceptual problems suggested by historical and recent artistic practice. No prior drawing experience necessary. Enrollment limited to 20 students. 1 Credit. Tuition: $2750. Session B: July 5 - August 6.
title: Basic Drawing
subject: ART

description: The focus of this course is on understanding wood technology and using machines and hand tools in the context of the studio. Students will be introduced to the range of what sculpture might be. Assignments are designed to foster hands-on appreciation of materials and craftsmanship, as well as initiate awareness of the aesthetic and political implications of handmade objects in a digital world. Attention is paid throughout the course to understanding and articulating form in space, and to helping students develop personal ways of working alongside, and in response to, current issues in contemporary sculpture. Group discussions and presentations complement the studio work. Enrollment limited to 16 students. 1 Credit. Tuition: $2750. Session B: July 5 - August 6.
title: Introductory Sculpture: Wood
subject: ART

description: An introduction to basic painting issues, stressing a beginning command of the conventions of pictorial space and the language of color. Class assignments and individual projects explore technical, conceptual, and historical issues central to the language of painting. Enrollment limited to 16 students. 1 Credit. Tuition: $2750. Session B: July 5 - August 6.
title: Painting Basics
subject: ART

description: A studio introduction to graphic design with emphasis on typography. In addition to typography, topics will include color, visual hierarchy, word/image relationships, and type in motion. Development of a verbal and visual vocabulary to discuss and critique typographic design for print and video or other screen-based work. Programs such as InDesign, Adobe Afteraffects, and Adobe Photoshop may be used for some projects in the computer facilities at the Yale School of Art. Enrollment limited to 16 students. 1 Credit. Tuition $2,950. Session B: July 5 - August 6.
title: Introduction to Graphic Design: Typography for Print and Video
subject: ART

description: Exploration of the transition of photographic processes and techniques into digital formats. A range of tools are presented including scanning, digital cameras, retouching, color correction, basic composition, and inkjet printing. Students produce original work throughout the technical component of the class. After mastering the basics, students work toward the completion of a final project, and the focus of the remaining classes is on critiques. Throughout the term, lectures and presentations raise critical issues concerning the impact of digital applications and by-products on the medium of photography. Students must have access to a digital camera and bring it to class. Enrollment limited to 16 students. 1 Credit. Tuition $2,950. Session B: July 5 - August 6.
title: Introduction to Digital Photography
subject: ART

description: Digital video represents a provocative combination of vernacular and classical styles through its ease of use and its potential for extremely high production values. This class introduces the basic tools of digital video production. Topics include DV camera operation, sound, and Mac-based editing. After students learn these basic techniques, the remainder of the class consists of individual and collaborative assignments that explore the visual language and production challenges of DV. This class is directed to the spatial and visual aspects of the medium rather than the narrative. The class also includes screenings of experimental films, video art, and DV feature films.  1 Credit. Tuition: $2,750. Session B: July 5 - August 6.
title: Introduction to Digital Video
subject: ART

description: A studio introduction to typographic communication on the internet. Students will conceive, design, and build a website and a content management system. The relationship between web server, web browser, content author, graphic designer, and user will be emphasized as both technical issues and aesthetic opportunities. Sustainability and evolution of a website over time is emphasized. HTML, CSS, image preparation, and basics of a server-side language (PHP or Ruby) will be taught utilizing the computer facilities at the Yale School of Art. No previous knowledge necessary. Enrollment limited to 16 students. 1 Credit. Tuition $2,950. Session B: July 5 - August 6.
title: Introduction to Interactive Design: World Wide Web
subject: ART

description: For non-science majors. An introduction to stars and planetary systems. Topics include the solar system and extrasolar planets, planet and star formation, and the evolution of stars from birth to death. No prerequisite other than a working knowledge of elementary algebra. 1 Credit. Tuition: $2750. Session A: May 31 - July 2.

subject: ASTR

description: This course serves as both an introduction to as well as an exploration of American literature from the nineteenth century to the present.  We will ask many questions of these texts, not the least of which is "what do we mean when we say 'American?'"  Given the wide range of the body of work that comprises American literature, however, we will also periodically ask in passing what we mean by "literature," so as to consider what roles the literary plays in creating and shaping the possibilities of social imagination, private and public discourse, as well as one's own identity. Emphasis on analytical reading, critical writing, and class discussions. Authors include Melville, Poe, Hawthorne, Whitman, Dickinson, Barnes, Toomer, H. Crane, W. C. Williams, L. Hughes, and M. Robinson. 1 Credit. Tution: $2,750. Session A: May 31 - July 2.

description: A course that combines both fiction and nonfiction writing, conducted as a workshop. Students will have the opportunity to write short fiction, memoir, and journalistic nonfiction. They may concentrate in one genre, or, if they wish, experiment with genres new to them. A brief writing sample in the course subject area is required and should be emailed to summer.session@yale.edu separately. Application deadline: May 10. Enrollment limited to 15. 1 Credit. description: Offered in Paris, France. Paris is the cultural capital of cinema. No city has been celebrated in film as frequently and as lovingly as Paris has. This course is an introduction to French cinema and culture from 1915 to the present which focuses on the mystery, romance, youth and consumerism of Paris. The class will visit film locations and museums such as Le Forum des Images, Le Centre Pompidou and La Cinémathèque Française as well as attend weekly cinema screenings. Films will include Les Vampires, Breathless, Les Amants de Pont-Neuf, La Haine, and Amélie. All readings will be in English with further optional readings in French. Scott Fitzgerald's The Last Tycoon, Budd Schulberg's What Makes Sammy Run, and Gore Vidal's Myra Breckenridge. Films include What Price Hollywood? A Star Is Born, Sunset Boulevard, In a Lonely Place, The Star, and The Player. 1 Credit. Tuition: $2750. Session A: May 31 - July 2.

description: An intensive, comprehensive hands-on workshop in which the problems and aesthetics of filmmaking are studied in practice as well as theory. Students learn the narrative film form and its collaborative nature by participating in the production process. By screening classic narrative masterpieces they will gain a sense of the medium's historical and aesthetic as well as develop a common vocabulary and point of reference with their fellow collaborators. The students will begin with seminars, readings and exercises that cover working with actors, script analysis, producing, camera, lighting, sound and editing and then move on to an actual production where as a group they make a short HD movie. Film professionals from various areas of expertise instruct and guide students in the application of industry standards to the exercises projects. The course is fully integrated with FILM S203 to provide filmmakers with a pool of acting talent and enable students to move beyond the technological requirements of the medium. This workshop requires a full daily commitment of the student's time, including 5 hours of classroom instruction, 2 hours of screenings, 1-2 hours of reading homework and workshop projects outside of class time and on weekends.  Enrollment limited to 16. 2 Credits. Tuition $5,300. More information on course web page: http://www.yale.edu/summer/programs/film/filmmaking.html. Dates: June 14 - July 23.
title: Intensive Filmmaking Workshop
subject: FILM

description: An intensive, full-time, hands-on workshop that is fully integrated with the Intensive Filmmaking Workshop (Film S-202) which allows the student actor to solve the artistic problems and technical challenges of film acting. Students begin with exercises that acclimate them to the tenets of good acting under the pressures and demands of the filmic medium. Then, with rehearsed scene work, they learn the technical language of cinema and they participate in various filmmaking practices. Their knowledge and techniques are tested by acting in one or more of the films produced by the Intensive Filmmaking Workshop. With the Filmmaking Workshop, the students screen classic narrative masterpieces nightly in order to gain a sense of the medium's historical and aesthetic context as well as to develop a common vocabulary and point of reference with fellow collaborators. Screenings, readings, and rehearsals supplement practical application. Daily commitments include, but are not limited to: 3-5 hours daily of classroom instruction, 2.5 hours of nightly screenings, 1-3 hours daily reading, rehearsal and shooting sessions outside of classroom time and on weekends. Enrollment limited to 16. 2 Credits. Tuition $5,300. More information on course web page: http://www.yale.edu/summer/programs/film/acting.html. Dates: June 14 - July 23, M-Th  9.30-12.30; M, W 2-4; Screenings M-Th 7-10 P.M.

subject: FILM

description: An examination of the key events and ideas that shape the modern motion picture business from financial, institutional, and historical standpoints. Topics include ways that the business has evolved in response to changes in technology, distribution, and competition; how the business dictates what ends up on screen; and relationships among studios, actors, agents, independent filmmakers, distributors, and the viewing audience. Industry practitioners discuss special topics. 1 Credit. Tuition $2,750. Session B: July 5 ¿ August 6.
title: Money and Media: the Business of Hollywood
subject: FILM

description: This course will examine the representation and documentation of American history on film and digital video, through the close analysis of a series of narrative fiction features depicting a wide variety of historical periods and major events in the nation's history. Topics will include Contact, the Civil War and Reconstruction, the Great Depression, World War II, the Cold War, Watergate and September 11th. This course seeks to expand its students' knowledge of the history of American film, culture and society, and to encourage its students to think analytically about how movies express historical content. In-class screenings will include Scarface, Gone with the Wind, The Outlaw Josey Wales, Gangs of New York, The New World, United 93 and Inglourious Basterds. 1 Credit. Tuition $2,750. Session B: July 5 - August 6.
title: Film, Video, and American History
subject: FILM

description: Introduction to the analysis of film and the study of black popular culture through Spike Lee's films. Close textual analysis of Lee's styles, sources, creative dilemmas, and collaborations. Topics include feminism and the erotic, sex/sexuality/gender, concepts of black leadership, cinematic reflexivity, early film history, race and racism, stereotypes, auteur theory, and questions of audience and authenticity.  1 Credit. Tuition: $2750. Session A: May 31 - July 2.
title: Spike Lee
subject: FILM

description: A seminar and workshop in screenplay writing. Students learn the basics of the craft by reading existing scripts, looking at films from a writer's perspective, and writing a short screenplay. Additional hours of individual screenings required. Enrollment limited to 15. 1 Credit. Tuition: $2750. Session A: May 31 - July 2.
title: Screenwriting
subject: FILM

description: Study of films by some of cinema's most ambitious directors, including Mervyn Leroy, Nicholas Ray, Kubrick, Polanski, Eastwood, and the Coen brothers. What these filmmakers attempted to say about the controversial state of the world and the viewer's precarious place in it. Attention to ways in which the directors visualized and reworked screenplays. 1 Credit. Tuition $2,750. Session B: July 5 - August 6.
title: Major American Directors and Their Films
subject: FILM

description: Exploration of film noir as an international form. Key noir films made in the United States, Britain, France, and Japan during World War II and the postwar era. Focus on visual style and on the ways in which these atmospheric, morally ambiguous crime dramas are related to, and comment upon, developments in the larger culture. Attention to the roots of film noir in the visual arts and fiction, its changes over the course of the 1940s and 1950s, and its influence on subsequent filmmaking. Course includes 35mm film screenings as well as trips to the Yale Art Gallery and the Museum of Modern Art. 1 Credit. Tuition: $2750. Session A: May 31 - July 2.
title: International Film Noir
subject: FILM

description: Examines crime drama, reality TV, crime news, crime networks, and crime documentaries.  Analysis of how the news media, community, law enforcement, criminals, and progressive and conservative pundits shape public views on criminality, law enforcement, violence, due process and judicial responsibility, as well as race, class, gender, and sexuality. This semester long-time "60 Minutes" CBS news correspondent Steve Kroft will visit to discuss his personal experience of news media shaping public attitudes. 1 Credit. Tuition $2,750. Session A: May 31 - July 2.
title: Television and Crime
subject: FILM

description: An introductory analysis of the television situation comedy in America from its beginnings in the 1950s to the present time. Exploration of how this popular and powerful genre grew and changed, how it influenced America, and how it was influenced by America in its depictions of family life, race and ethnicity, stereotypes, fantasy, feminism, war, progressive forms of cultural and racial inclusion, and contemporary looks at single life and gay liberation. Field trip to include the Museum of the Moving Image and the Museum of Broadcast in New York. 1 Credit. Tuition $2,750. Session B: July 5 - August 6.
title: Television Situation Comedy
subject: FILM

description: Intensive training and practice in all the language skills through extensive use of audio and video material, with an initial emphasis on listening and speaking. Authentic, unsimplified French is used as in actual situations. Emphasis on communicative proficiency, the development of skills, self-expression, and cultural insights. Classes are supplemented by regular laboratory assignments. Conducted entirely in French. Daily classroom and laboratory attendance is required. For students with no previous study of French. 1 1/2 credits. Must be taken in conjunction with FREN S120 in the same summer for credit. Tuition: $2750. Session A: May 31 - July 2.
title: Elementary and Intermediate French
subject: FREN

description: Continuation of FREN S110. 1 1/2 Credits. Must be taken in conjunction with FREN S110 in the same summer for credit. Tuition: $2750. Session B: July 5 - August 6.
title: Elementary and Intermediate French
subject: FREN

description: Part 1 of an intensive "at-home-and-abroad" course designed to perfect students' skills in understanding spoken and written French and in speaking and writing. Prepares students for further work in literary, language, and cultural studies as well as for nonacademic use of French. Conducted entirely in French. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Paris, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: April 1. Must be taken in conjunction with FREN S140. Prerequisite: FREN 120, 121 or equivalent. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $2,750. Course dates: June 7 - July 2.
title: Intermediate and Advanced French I
subject: FREN

description: Offered in Paris, France. Part 2 of an intensive "at-home-and-abroad" course designed to perfect students' skills in understanding spoken and written French and in speaking and writing. Prepares students for further work in literary, language, and cultural studies as well as for nonacademic use of French. Conducted entirely in French. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Paris, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: April 1. Must be taken in conjunction with FREN S130. Prerequisite: FREN 120, 121 or equivalent.  Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $2,750. Course dates: July 5 - July 30.
title: Intermediate and Advanced French II
subject: FREN

description: Offered in Paris, France. An advanced language course intended to improve students' comprehension of spoken and written French as well as their speaking and writing skills. Excursions to museums, movies, and theaters complement the reading of modern fiction and nonfiction texts. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Paris, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: April 1. Prerequisite: after FREN 140, 145, or equivalent. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 Credit. Tuition $2,750. Session A: May 31 - July 2.
title: Advanced Language Practice II
subject: FREN

description: Offered in Paris, France. Intensive oral practice for advanced students. An introduction to contemporary French culture and current events while sharing day-to-day life with Parisians. In small groups, students conduct surveys and interviews, melding the techniques of ethnography and photojournalism. Classroom activities include students' presentation of their findings; discussions and debates based on readings of newspapers and other periodicals; films; songs; stories; and clips from French television. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Paris, costs of room and board in Paris, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: April 1. Prerequisite: after FREN 150, 151, or equivalent proficiency. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 Credit. Tuition $2,750. Session A: May 31 - July 2.
title: Advanced Culture and Conversation
subject: FREN

description: Offered in Paris, France. Conducted in English. Study of the culture and monuments of the High Middle Ages in France. Gothic architecture, urban and economic renewal, and intellectual life in twelfth- and thirteenth-century Paris. Discussion of historical and literary works by Abelard, Suger, Rutebeuf, Saint Bernard, Joinville, and Thibaut de Champagne. Visits to Notre-Dame de Paris, Saint Denis, Chartres, Sainte-Chapelle, and Cluny. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Paris, costs of room and board in Paris, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: April 1. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 2 Credits. Tuition $5,300. Session B: July 5 - August 6.
title: Age of Cathedrals
subject: FREN

description: Offered in Paris, France. Conducted in French. A reading of the poetry and major prose of Charles Baudelaire, using the city of Paris as a source of information and insight. Neighborhoods, buildings, monuments, museums, public artworks, and library collections frame Baudelaire's writings as multifaceted responses to changes in the nineteenth-century urban environment. Works include The Flowers of Evil and Paris Spleen. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Paris, costs of room and board in Paris, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: April 1. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. Prerequisite: FREN 151b or equivalent. 1 Credit. Tuition $2,750. Session B: July 5 - August 6.
short_title: Baudelaire: A Poet in the City
title: Baudelaire: A Poet in the City
subject: FREN

description: An interdisciplinary introduction to Surrealism. Particular focus on manifestos, visual arts, and surrealist texts. Includes works by Artaud, Bunuel, Breton, Desnos, Duchamp, Eluard, Jacob, Leiris, Man Ray, Picasso, Soupault, Tzara. Course taught in English. Reading knowledge of French recommended but not required. 1 Credit. Tuition: $2750. Session B: July 5 - August 6.
title: Surrealism: Image and Text
subject: FREN

description: Primarily for graduate students preparing to pass French reading examinations who have had no (or minimal) previous study of French. A programmed course in which the student acquires the structural essentials of grammar and a basic vocabulary through the reading of texts in various fields of interest as determined by the students. May not be taken with any other foreign language reading course. Conducted in English. No Credits. Tuition $1,375. Session A: May 31 - July 2.
title: French for Reading
subject: FREN

description: Part 1 of an intensive, "at-home-and-abroad," content-based language course that teaches linguistic skills through a variety of literary and nonfiction texts and film, with special emphasis on the culture and history of Berlin. Application deadline: April 1. Must be taken in conjunction with GMAN S140. Prerequisite: GMAN 120 or equivalent. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $2,750. Course dates: May 31 - June 25.
title: Intermediate German I
subject: GMAN

description: Offered in Berlin, Germany. Part 2 of an intensive, "at-home-and-abroad," content-based language course that teaches linguistic skills through a variety of literary and nonfiction texts and film, with special emphasis on the culture and history of Berlin. Must be taken in conjunction with GMAN S130. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Berlin, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: April 1. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $2,750. Course dates June 28 - July 23.
title: Intermediate German II
subject: GMAN

description: Primarily for graduate students preparing to pass departmental language reading examinations who have had no previous study in German. In the first part of the course, students acquire the basic vocabulary and structure of the language through analytical discussion of grammar and extensive reading of programmed simple texts. In the second part, students read and discuss specialized materials in the fields of the humanities, the natural sciences, and the social sciences as determined by class interest and participation. Extensive translation work is required of all students. Conducted in English. May not be taken with any other foreign language reading course. No Credits. Tuition $1,375. Session A: May 31 - July 2.
title: German for Reading
subject: GMAN

description: Primarily for graduate students preparing to pass departmental language reading examinations who have had no previous study in German. In the first part of the course, students acquire the basic vocabulary and structure of the language through analytical discussion of grammar and extensive reading of programmed simple texts. In the second part, students read and discuss specialized materials in the fields of the humanities, the natural sciences, and the social sciences as determined by class interest and participation. Extensive translation work is required of all students. Conducted in English. May not be taken with any other foreign language reading course. No Credits. Tuition $1,375. Session A: May 31 - July 2.
title: German for Reading
subject: GMAN

description: Introduction to ancient Greek. Emphasis on morphology and syntax within a structured program of readings and exercises. Prepares for GREK S120. No prior knowledge of Greek assumed. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition: $2750. Session A: May 31 - July 2.
title: Beginning Greek: The Elements of Grammar
subject: GREK

description: Continuation of GREK S110.  Emphasis on consolidating grammar and on readings from Greek authors. The sequence GREK S110, S120 prepares for GREK 131 or 141.  Prerequisite: GREK S110 or equivalent. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition: $2750. Session B: July 5 - August 6.
title: Beginning Greek: Review of Grammar and Selected Readings
subject: GREK

description: Key topics in the history of New England since the end of the Civil War. Changing social, economic, and political realities; shifting conceptions of regional identity promoted by inhabitants and outsiders. Factors that have made New England at once prototypical and atypical within the United States amidst broader transformations in American society. Topics include immigration and migration, industrialization and deindustrialization, agricultural decline and tourism, urban renewal, defense spending and high technology, racial and ethnic conflict, environmental movements, gay rights, and professional sports. 1 Credit. Tuition $2,750. Session B: July 5 - August 6.
title: New England: Region and Identity, 1865-present
subject: HIST

description: The cultural, social, and political life of United States cities. Major themes include the definition of public and private space, the role of cities in fostering vibrant subcultures, and cities' potential both to segregate and to integrate diverse populations. Sources introduce urban politics, planning, and social movements, and provide perspectives on the city from literature, visual art, and film. 1 Credit. Tuition: $2750. Session A: May 31 - July 2.
title: The American City, 1800-present
subject: HIST

description: The rise of the idea of leisure within American society, and the particular forms that idea has taken. We will consider the amateur sports and the recreational habits that won popularity in the U.S. from the end of the nineteenth through the late twentieth centuries. We will also evaluate the place of professional sports from a legal and business perspective. 1 Credit. Tuition: $2750. Session B: July 5 - August 6.
title: Sports, Leisure, and Recreation in American Culture, 1880-1980
subject: HIST

description: The history of both westward expansion and continental conquest explored from the perspectives of the people who saw it, experienced it, and made it happen, including European settlers, Native Americans, and African slaves. Major events and people, from the Overland Trail to the Massacre at Wounded Knee, from Daniel Boone to Black Hawk, spanning more than three hundred years of North American history. Research will include the use of Overland Diaries from the Beinecke Rare Books Library. 1 Credit. Tuition $2,750. Session B: July 5 - August 6.
short_title: The History of the American West
title: The History of the American West
subject: HIST

description: The extent to which ideas about disease, healthcare institutions and practitioners, and medical knowledge have been shaped by national settings; focus on the United States. The influence of international collaboration on medical epistemology and clinical practice. The relationship between American medical organizations and institutions and those of other countries. Distinctive American attitudes toward health and disease.  1 Credit. Tuition $2,750. Session A: May 31 - July 2.
title: "Science Knows No Country": American Medicine in a Global Context, 1850-2010
subject: HIST

description: Examination of the social, cultural, and political phenomenon known as the Harlem Renaissance. Topics include resistance to oppression, autonomy, the intersection between culture and politics, and the place of the Harlem Renaissance within the larger struggle for equality. Readings from both primary and secondary sources. 1 Credit. Tuition: $2750. Session B: July 5 - August 6.
title: New Negro Arts and Politics
subject: HIST

description: This course will examine the representation and documentation of American history on film and digital video, through the close analysis of a series of narrative fiction features depicting a wide variety of historical periods and major events in the nation's history. Topics will include Contact, the Civil War and Reconstruction, the Great Depression, World War II, the Cold War, Watergate and September 11th. This course seeks to expand its students' knowledge of the history of American film, culture and society, and to encourage its students to think analytically about how movies express historical content. In-class screenings will include Scarface, Gone with the Wind, The Outlaw Josey Wales, Gangs of New York, The New World, United 93 and Inglourious Basterds. 1 Credit. Tuition $2,750. Session B: July 5 - August 6.
title: Film, Video, and American History
subject: HIST

description: An introduction to intellectual and cultural life in Renaissance Europe (c. 1450-1700) as considered through the West's first major innovation in information technology, the printing press. Topics include the development of the book from antiquity, the shift from manuscript to print cultures, literacy and social change, authorship and intellectual property, and the history of early modern reading practices.  At least one session will be devoted to an explicit comparison of the age of print and the current digital/cyber age - sometimes referred to as the second "Gutenberg Revolution." Did information in the Renaissance, as now, "want to be free"? The course is taught at the Beinecke Rare Book Library through a series of first-hand encounters with manuscripts, books, prints, and other rare objects, which students will use as part of their coursework. The class will also include visits to the British Art Center, the Yale University Art Gallery, and other collections. 1 Credit. Tuition $2,750. Session B: July 5-August 6.
title: Information Technologies and the Renaissance Printing Revolution
subject: HIST

description: Offered in Paris, France. Social, political, and cultural changes in Old-Regime and Revolutionary France from the reign of Louis XIV to the Napoleonic Empire. Focus on how these transformations took place in Paris and Versailles. Topics include absolutism, state building, court culture, corporate life (guilds), ritual, civility, urbanization, the Enlightenment, the public sphere, the Revolution of 1789, and the rise of Napoleon. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Paris, room and board costs in France, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: April 1. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 Credit. Tuition $2,750. Session A: May 24 - June 24.
title: French Absolutism, Enlightenment, and Revolution, 1680-1800
subject: HIST

description: Examination of ways in which food preferences have affected European and North American history from 500 B.C. to the present. How taste has interacted with trade, cultural contacts, and technology. The influence of the environment and migration on cuisine; the effects of food on historical developments such as colonial expansion, slavery, and globalization. 1 Credit. Tuition: $2750. Session A: May 31 - July 2.
title: History of Food and Cuisine
subject: HIST

description: Focusing on Europe's multi-ethnic imperial states (Russia/Soviet Union, the Ottoman state, and Austria-Hungary), this course explores the theme of empire from a transnational perspective. Topics to be examined include: the common institutions and practices produced by empires; the ways that imperial modes of governance shaped social and political life; and the factors that hold empires together and drive them to collapse. 1 Credit. Tuition $2,750. Session B: July 5 - August 6.
title: The Imperial Experience in Modern Europe
subject: HIST

title: The Western World Since 1500
subject: HIST

title: Russia and the West
subject: HIST

title: From Crusade to Enlightenment
subject: HIST

description: A study of the Cold War as an event in international history, surveying its origins, course, conclusions, and legacy from the perspectives of its major participants. Topics include the Cold War's effects on society, culture and intellectual life. In addition to textbooks, students will also read recently declassified, published and translated American, Soviet, East European, Chinese, Korean, and Vietnamese documents. Film screenings will include Dr. Strangelove and Goodbye, Lenin! There will also be a field trip to the Cold War memorabilia and primary sources exhibition at Yale University Archives and an optional outing to a 1950s nuclear fallout shelter site. 1 Credit. Tuition $2,750. Session A: May 31 - July 2.
title: The Cold War
subject: HIST

description: Offered in Dubrovnik, Croatia. Multidisciplinary study of southeastern Europe from antiquity to modernity. Byzantine presence and the remnants of the Roman world; consequences of the schism between Rome and Constantinople; barbarian kingdoms and the medieval city-states; Ottoman incursions and millets; Renaissance and Baroque; beginning of nationalism and modern national integrations; national revolutions, fascism, communism, and postcommunist conflicts; secularization of religion; genocide in post-Yugoslav wars. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Dubrovnik, room and board costs in Croatia, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Must be taken in conjunction with SOCY S286. Application deadline: April 1. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 Credit. Tuition $2,650. Session B: July 5 - August 6.
title: History and Culture of Southeastern Europe
subject: HIST

description: Changes experienced by African societies during the era of the Atlantic slave trade. Focus on the complex interaction between the internal dynamics of African societies and the impact of outside forces. 1 Credit. Tuition: $2750. Session A: May 31 - July 2.
title: Africa and the Atlantic World 1450-1850
subject: HIST

description: Major conflicts, revolutions, and wars in the Persian Gulf during the nineteenth and twentieth centuries. Topics include conflicts between the Ottoman Empire, Iran, and Arab Gulf areas; Arab-Iranian rivalry; the role of Islam in state and society; tribal communities within states; British occupations; the emergence of Kuwait, Iraq, and modern Iran; revolutions in Iraq and Iran; and the twentieth-century Gulf Wars. 1 Credit. Tuition $2,750. Session A: May 31 - July 2.
short_title: Iran, Iraq, and the Persian Gulf
title: Iran, Iraq, and the Persian Gulf
subject: HIST

description: Introduction to the art and science of cartography, with a focus on historical connections between map making and power in Europe. Topics include the role of maps in European state formation, maritime exploration, colonial encounters, and urban planning. Study of recent works of map history and theory as well as primary sources from Sterling Memorial Library's Map Room. 1 Credit. Tuition $2,750. Session B: July 5 - August 6.
title: Mapping the World
subject: HIST

description: Offered in Mombasa, Kenya. Survey of the modern history of East Africa, with a focus on health, environment, and society. The rise of Swahili language and culture; slavery and plantation agriculture; colonial regimes, medical discourse, and environmental degradation; agrarian protest and nationalist mobilization; conservation ethics and national parks; female genital cutting; HIV/AIDS. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Mombasa, costs of room and board in Mombasa, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: April 1. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 2 Credits. Yale students may petition for one HU area credit. Tuition: $5,300. Session B: June 28 - August 7.
title: History of East Africa
subject: HIST

description: The emergence of internationalism during the final years of World War I and its immediate aftermath, and the descent toward obsolescence of the empire model in world politics. Responses to Woodrow Wilson's peace diplomacy and the League of Nations; the Russian revolution and the subsequent upheaval across Eurasia; the struggles for Indian, Irish, and Czech independence; the birth of modern nationalism in Asia. 1 Credit. Tuition: $2750. Session A: May 31 - July 2.
title: World Politics 1917-1919
subject: HIST

description: Offered in Monterrey, Mexico. Introduction to global health challenges, with a focus on diseases of the poor. Ethical dilemmas in global health research and control. Students work in field-based public health projects in partnership with local health agencies in Monterrey and students from Monterrey Tec University. Prerequisite: Spanish language through L2. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Mexico, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: April 1. Enrollment limited. For more information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 2 Credits. Tuition $5,300. Session A: May 31 - July 2.
title: Public Health in Action
subject: HLTH

description: A history of artistic expression from prehistory to the Renaissance. Selected studies of architecture, sculpture, and painting. Lectures in the classroom and gallery talks in the Yale University Art Gallery and Beinecke Library. 1 Credit. Tuition $2,750. Session A: May 31 - July 2.
title: Introduction to History of Art: Prehistory to the Renaissance
subject: HSAR

description: A survey of Western art from the fifteenth century to the present. Introduction to both the masterpieces of artistic expression and the methods for defining and interpreting those works. Field trips to Yale museums and architectural walking tours complement the study of paintings, sculptures, architecture, and domestic and luxury arts. Readings include survey texts and original sources. 1 Credit. Tuition $2,750. Session B: July 5 - August 6.
title: Introduction to History of Art: Renaissance to Modern
subject: HSAR

description: In-depth discussion of ten major works of Western art from the Renaissance to the modern era. Works selected both for their extraordinary qualities and for their capacity to represent a range of periods, places, media, themes, and functions. Includes visits to Yale's art museums to view corollary works of art; some attention to relevant poetry, literature, and film. 1 Credit. Tuition $2,750. Session B: July 5 - August 6.
title: Ten Works of Western Art
subject: HSAR

Distinctive American attitudes toward health and disease.  1 Credit. Tuition $2,750. Session A: May 31 - July 2.

description: This course examines the ways in which applied theater has been used to foster civic participation and to address social concerns such as racism, poverty, gender-based violence, access to health care, and education. 1 Credit. Tuition $2,750. Session B: July 5 - August 6.
title: Applied Theater, Trauma, Cultural Intervention
subject: HUMS

description: The changing meaning of the term "genius" from ancient Greece to the present. The nature of genius examined through the lives and working methods of exceptional individuals, including Mozart, da Vinci, Newton, Napoleon, and Joyce. Topics such as nature vs. nurture, prodigy, concentration, memory, and exceptional processing skills explored to define and establish markers for genius. Recent developments in neurobiology that may elucidate why some individuals possess extraordinary mental and artistic abilities. 1 Credit. Tuition $2,750. Session B: July 5 - August 6.
title: Brains of Genius: Mozart and Friends
subject: HUMS

description: Offered in Rome, Italy. Designed as the complement to HUMS 396b, this course will consider how Rome's contributions to western thought are recorded in the very fabric of the city. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Rome, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: March 1. Admission notifications will be made after March 1st. Prerequisite: HUMS 396b. Enrollment limited, with preference to Humanities majors and juniors. For further information please contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 2 Credits. Tuition $5,300. Session A: May 31 - July 2.
title: Rome
subject: HUMS

description: Offered in Auvillar, France. A program directed towards the liberal arts student and meant to provide a hands-on experience and understanding of the dynamics of the studio strategies for initiating, executing, developing and discussing work. It takes advantage of the special summer period outside of the student's normal responsibility to rigorously focus on personal issues of idea formulation, creative problem solving and studio research. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Auvillar, room and board costs in France, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: March 1. Interview required. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 2 Credits. Tuition $5,300. Course dates: May 31 - June 29.
title: Studio Practice in Painting and Drawing
subject: HUMS

Visits to Notre-Dame de Paris, Saint Denis, Chartres, Sainte-Chapelle, and Cluny.
