subject: HUMS

description: May be arranged for currently enrolled Yale students in Ecology and Evolutionary Biology; Engineering and Applied Science; Geology and Geophysics; Chemistry; Molecular Biophysics and Biochemistry; Molecular, Cellular, and Developmental Biology; Physics; or any other science department sponsoring such programs. These programs are especially useful for juniors in providing them with actual research experience prior to application to graduate or professional schools. Students wishing to enroll must complete the regular application for Yale Summer Session. In addition, students must submit written permission of (1) the faculty sponsor, who should also supply a l- or 2-paragraph description of the research to be undertaken including the proposed starting and ending dates, (2) the Director of Summer Sciences, and (3) the director of undergraduate studies of the applicant's major department. Students taking Independent Research for 1 credit must work 35 hours a week for five weeks (either Session A or B); for 2 credits students must work 35 hours a week for ten weeks (both Session A and B). Students may receive academic credit only if they are not being paid for doing research, but they may work for credit in one 5-week period and for pay in the other. 1 Credit. Tuition $2,750. Session A: May 31 - July 2.
title: Independent Research in the Sciences
subject: IDRS

description: May be arranged for currently enrolled Yale students in Ecology and Evolutionary Biology; Engineering and Applied Science; Geology and Geophysics; Chemistry; Molecular Biophysics and Biochemistry; Molecular, Cellular, and Developmental Biology; Physics; or any other science department sponsoring such programs. These programs are especially useful for juniors in providing them with actual research experience prior to application to graduate or professional schools. Students wishing to enroll must complete the regular application for Yale Summer Session. In addition, students must submit written permission of (1) the faculty sponsor, who should also supply a l- or 2-paragraph description of the research to be undertaken including the proposed starting and ending dates, (2) the Director of Summer Sciences, and (3) the director of undergraduate studies of the applicant's major department. Students taking Independent Research for 1 credit must work 35 hours a week for five weeks (either Session A or B); for 2 credits students must work 35 hours a week for ten weeks (both Session A and B). Students may receive academic credit only if they are not being paid for doing research, but they may work for credit in one 5-week period and for pay in the other. 1 Credit. Tuition $2,750. Session B: July 5 - August 6.
title: Independent Research in the Sciences
subject: IDRS

description: First part of an intensive "at-home-and-abroad" course. A beginning course with extensive practice in speaking, reading, writing, and listening and a thorough introduction to Italian grammer. Activities include group and pairs work, role-playing, and conversation. Introduction to Italian culture through reading and films. Conducted in Italian. Must be taken in conjunction with ITAL S120. Credit only on completion of ITAL 120. Application deadline: April 1. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $2,750. Course dates: May 31 - June 18.
title: Elementary Italian I
subject: ITAL

description: Offered in Siena, Italy. Second part of an intensive "at-home-and-abroad" course. A continuation of ITAL S110. Conducted in Italian. Must be taken in conjunction with ITAL S110. Prerequisite: ITAL 110 (Elementary Italian I). Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Siena, room and board costs in Italy, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: April 1. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $2,750. Course dates: June 21 - July 23.
title: Elementary Italian II
subject: ITAL

description: First part of an intensive "at-home-and-abroad" course designed for second-year Italian students, combining language study at the intermediate level with an exploration of Italian literature, film, and culture. Students complete the equivalent of one term of intermediate Italian during the three weeks on the Yale campus, followed by the equivalent of one term of intermediate Italian during the five weeks in Italy. The second half of the course allows students to put their language skills into practice, and provides for trips and cultural encounters in the Tuscany region. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Siena, room and board costs in Italy, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: April 1. Prerequisite: ITAL 120 (Elementary Italian II) or equivalent. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $2,750.  3 Weeks: May 31 - June 18.
title: Intermediate Italian I
subject: ITAL

description: Offered in Siena, Italy. Second part of an intensive "at-home-and-abroad" course designed for second-year Italian students, combining language study at the intermediate level with an exploration of Italian literature, film, and culture. Students complete the equivalent of one term of intermediate Italian during the three weeks on the Yale campus, followed by the equivalent of one term of intermediate Italian during the five weeks in Italy. The second half of the course allows students to put their language skills into practice, and provides for trips and cultural encounters in the Tuscany region. Must be taken in conjunction with ITAL S130. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Siena, room and board costs in Italy, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: April 1. Prerequisite: ITAL 130 (Intermediate Italian I) or equivalent. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $2,750.  5 Weeks: June 21 - July 23.
title: Intermediate Italian II
subject: ITAL

description: Offered in Siena, Italy. The origins, development, and maturation of the Renaissance in Florence. The city's political debates, ideals of education, Neoplatonic enthusiasms, literature, and art. The Florentine Renaissance compared to those of Ferrara and Rome. Includes visits to Florence, Rome, and Ferrara. Application deadline: April 1. Enrollment limited. 1 Credit. Tuition $2,750. 5 weeks: June 18 - July 23.
title: The Florentine Renaissance
subject: ITAL

description: For graduate and undergraduate students preparing to pass Italian reading examinations who have had no (or minimal) prior study of Italian.  Students acquire fundamental grammar structures and basic vocabulary through the reading of texts in various fields, primarily humanities and social sciences (others as determined by student interest). Conducted in English. No Credits. Tuition $1,375. Session A: May 31 - July 2.
title: Italian for Reading
subject: ITAL

description: Introduction to Latin. Emphasis on morphology and syntax within a structured program of readings and exercises. Prepares for LATN 120.  No prior knowledge of Latin assumed. Primarily for graduate students. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition: $2750. Session A: May 31 - July 2.
title: Beginning Latin: The Elements of Grammar
subject: LATN

description: Continuation of LATN 110. Emphasis on consolidating grammar and on readings from Latin authors. The sequence LATN 110, 120 prepares for 131 or 141. Prerequisite: LATN 110 or equivalent. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition: $2750. Session B: July 5 - August 6.
title: Beginning Latin: Review of Grammar and Selected Readings
subject: LATN

description: An intensive introduction of Latin prose. Readings will vary from year to year, and may include selections from Cicero, Sallust, Livy, Tacitus, and other prose authors. Close attention to syntax, style, and translation techniques are balanced by literary interpretation and consideration of the works in a wider cultural context. Prepares for introductory Latin poetry (LATN 301) or a 400-level course upon recommendation of the director of undergraduate studies. Prerequisite: one year of college Latin. 1 Credit. Tuition: $2750. Session A: May 31 - July 2.
title: Latin Prose: An Introduction
subject: LATN

description: Offered in Mumbai, India. Study of the linguistic landscape of India, focusing particularly on the Indo-Aryan and Dravidian linguistic areas. The historical evolution of the multilingual landscape over time, and its political and social implications in contemporary India. Must be taken in conjunction with SAST S305/ANTH S305. Students are responsible for all travels expenses to and from India, room and board costs, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: April 1. Enrollment limited. For more information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 Credit. Tuition $2,650. Session A: May 31 - July 2.
title: A Linguistic History of India
subject: LING

description: Examination of how stories are told in both literary and nonliterary texts, with special attention to the act of decoding and interpreting a narrative. Emphasis on fictional form, the mechanics of plot, and questions of time and character. Topics include confession, memory, language, the representation of the self, the interplay of form and content, and the relationship between fiction and history. 1 Credit. Tuition: $2750. Session A: May 31 - July 2.
title: Introduction to Narrative
subject: LITR

description: Offered in Paris, France. Conducted in English. Study of the culture and monuments of the High Middle Ages in France. Gothic architecture, urban and economic renewal, and intellectual life in twelfth- and thirteenth-century Paris. Discussion of historical and literary works by Abelard, Suger, Rutebeuf, Saint Bernard, Joinville, and Thibaut de Champagne. Visits to Notre-Dame de Paris, Saint Denis, Chartres, Sainte-Chapelle, and Cluny. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Paris, room and board costs in France, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: April 1. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 2 Credits. Tuition $5,300. Session B: July 5 - August 6.
title: Age of Cathedrals
subject: LITR

description: An introductory survey of Italian, French, and English Renaissance love poetry, including drama and romance, as well as contemporary thought about love. Readings include poems and essays by Plato, Petrarch, Dante, Ariosto, Ronsard, Montaigne, Sidney, Spenser, Shakespeare, Marvell, and Donne. Readings in translation. 1 Credit. Tuition $2,750. Session B: July 5 - August 6.
title: Renaissance Love Poetry
subject: LITR

description: Exploration of various theoretical and practical problems in translation. Topics include the responsibility of the translator to the text, the author and the reader; the reliability of translation as a literary mode; the transmission or perversion of culture via translation; and the specific problems involved with the translation of various genres (poetry, drama, fiction, non-fiction). 1 Credit. Tuition $2750. Session A: May 31 - July 2.
title: Translation: Literature and Practice
subject: LITR

description: Offered in Paris, France. A reading of the poetry and major prose of Charles Baudelaire, using the city of Paris as a source of information and insight. Neighborhoods, buildings, monuments, museums, public artworks, and library collections frame Baudelaire's writings as multifaceted responses to changes in the nineteenth-century urban environment. Works include The Flowers of Evil and Paris Spleen. Conducted in French. Students are responsible for travel expenses to and from Paris, room and board costs in France, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: 1 April. Enrollment limited. Prerequisite: FREN 151b or equivalent. 1 Credit. Tuition $2,750. Session B: July 5 - August 6.
short_title: Baudelaire: A Poet in the City
title: Baudelaire: A Poet in the City
subject: LITR

description: The complex relationship between religion and literature from the nineteenth century to the present. Focus on the Greco-Roman and Judeo-Christian traditions. Modernity and tradition, the legitimacy of ritual, the relationship between church and state, and the reception of antiquity. The emergence of modern discourses of gender and sexuality in light of religious practice and dogma. 1 Credit. Tuition: $2750. Session A: May 31 - July 2.
title: Irreverent Texts: Religion and Literature
subject: LITR

description: Limits, continuity, differentiation of elementary and transcendental functions, applications. No prior acquaintance with calculus is assumed. Pre-college students should consider enrolling in this course only if they have a strong foundation in algebra. 1 Credit. Tuition $2,750. Session B: July 5 - August 6.
title: Calculus of Functions of One Variable I
subject: MATH

description: The definite integral, fundamental theorem of calculus, techniques of integration, polar coordinates, Taylor series, applications. Prerequisite: one term of calculus of functions of one variable (MATH 112 or equivalent). 1 Credit. Tuition $2,750. Session B: July 5 - August 6.
title: Calculus of Functions of One Variable II
subject: MATH

description: (Formerly "Mathematics for Economists".) Calculus of functions of several variables, with some linear algebra. Intended for students in the social sciences, especially those majoring in Economics. Prerequisite: one term of calculus of functions of one variable (MATH 112 or equivalent). Yale students may not take this course after MATH 120 or 222. 1 Credit. Tuition $2,750. Session B: July 5 - August 6.
title: Introduction to Functions of Several Variables
subject: MATH

description: Analytic geometry in three dimensions, using vectors. Real-valued functions of two and three variables, partial derivatives, gradient and directional derivatives, level curves and surfaces, maxima and minima. Parametrized curves in space, motion in space, line integrals; applications. Prerequisite: two terms of calculus of functions of one variable (MATH 112 and 115 or equivalent). 1 Credit. Tuition $2,750. Session B: July 5 - August 6.
title: Calculus of Functions of Several Variables
subject: MATH

description: Introduction to biochemistry, genetics, cell biology, and early development. Emphasis on the cell as the basic unit of life; the cell's composition, functions, replication, and differentiation. This course, with laboratory, meets departmental requirements for the major, and is appropriate for students seeking to fulfill medical school requirements. Students are encouraged to take this course with the laboratory, MCDB S-121, which together constitute a full course load. 1 Credit. Tuition $2,750. Session B: July 5 - August 6.
title: Principles of Molecular, Cellular and Developmental Biology
subject: MCDB

description: Experimental techniques and procedures in molecular and cell biology. 1/2 Credit. Tuition $1,375. Session B: July 5 - August 6.
title: Laboratory for Principles of Molecular, Cellular and Developmental Biology
subject: MCDB

description: A comprehensive course in cell and molecular biology. Emphasis on general principles of cell function and rationale and design of pertinent biomedical experiments. 1 Credit. Tuition: $2,750. Session A: May 31- July 2.
title: Cell Biology
subject: MCDB

description: The complex relationship between religion and literature from the nineteenth century to the present. Focus on the Greco-Roman and Judeo-Christian traditions. Modernity and tradition, the legitimacy of ritual, the relationship between church and state, and the reception of antiquity. The emergence of modern discourses of gender and sexuality in light of religious practice and dogma. 1 Credit. Tuition: $2750. Session A: May 31 - July 2.
title: Irreverent Texts: Religion and Literature
subject: MGRK

description: Social movement and network theory used to analyze the emergence and evolution of Islamic movements from the early twentieth century to the present. Organization, mobilization, and framing of political, nonpolitical, militant, and nonmilitant movements; transnational dimensions of Islamic activism. Case studies include the Muslim Brotherhood, Hamas, Hizbollah, Al-Qaeda, Al-Adl wa-Ihsann, and Tablighi Jama'at. 1 Credit. Tuition $2,750. Session A: May 31 - July 2.
title: Islamic Social Movements
subject: MMES

description: The effects of globalization on Muslim religious and political practices. The complex relationships between the globalization of Islam and issues of secularization, fundamentalism, and migration. The growing disconnection between religion and culture. Material and intellectual movements that have affected Islamic practice since the early 1990s. Muslim immigration in Western countries and ways in which Western Islam influences religious practices and political discourse in Muslim-majority countries. The increasing appeal of Islam to converts in Latin America and western Europe. 1 Credit. Tuition $2,750. Session B: July 5 - August 6.
title: The Globalization of Islam
subject: MMES

description: Survey of debates in the modern and contemporary Arab world concerning heritage, secularism, religion, language, gender equality, modernization, and tradition. Readings in translation include Arab and Western writings from the late nineteenth century to the present. Focus on gender identities in relation to nationalism, Islamism, and the West, and on how such identities are reflected in different genres. 1 Credit. Tuition: $2750. Session B: July 5 - August 6.
title: Introduction to Modern Middle East Studies
subject: MMES

description: Introduction to the integration of music and technology. Topics include digital notation; digital recording and mixing; digital sampling and synthesis; and MIDI sequencing. Intended for students who have no prior experience with music software and hardware tools and may not have the ability to read music. Enrollment limited to 10 students. 1 Credit. Tuition $2,750. Session A: May 31 - July 2.
title: Introduction to Music and Technology
subject: MUSI

description: The changing meaning of the term "genius" from ancient Greece to the present. The nature of genius examined through the lives and working methods of exceptional individuals, including Mozart, da Vinci, Newton, Napoleon, and Joyce. Topics such as nature vs. nurture, prodigy, concentration, memory, and exceptional processing skills explored to define and establish markers for genius. Recent developments in neurobiology that may elucidate why some individuals possess extraordinary mental and artistic abilities. 1 Credit. Tuition $2,750. Session B: July 5 - August 6.
title: Brains of Genius: Mozart and Friends
subject: MUSI

description: Introduction to jazz from its beginnings to 1960. The growth of jazz from its roots in African music through its development in New Orleans to its evolutionary expansion up the Mississippi and throughout the United States. A study of jazz's greatest artists and their styles; selected music of each jazz period; and the sociological factors surrounding the genre's development. While no extensive music theory background or formal instrumental experience is required, students who can read music will be best prepared to fulfill the listening and form identification assignments. 1 Credit. Tuition $2,750. Session A: May 31 - July 2.
title: Introduction to the History of Jazz
subject: MUSI

description: Investigation of popular music as an expression of cultural identities in the United States from the end of World War II to the present, including genres such as blues, rock, soul, funk, alternative, and rap. 1 Credit. Tuition $2,750. Session B: July 5 - August 6.
title: American Pop Music Since 1945
subject: MUSI

description: Survey of debates in the modern and contemporary Arab world concerning heritage, secularism, religion, language, gender equality, modernization, and tradition. Readings in translation include Arab and Western writings from the late nineteenth century to the present. Focus on gender identities in relation to nationalism, Islamism, and the West, and on how such identities are reflected in different genres. 1 Credit. Tuition: $2750. Session B: July 5 - August 6.
title: Introduction to Modern Middle East Studies
subject: NELC

description: 3 credit hours. Community health nurses provide preventive, therapeutic, rehabilitation, and hospice services across the life span. The clinical experience focuses on the delivery of these health services in domestic community organizations. Nursing responsibility for caseload management offers an opportunity to interact with other members of the interdisciplinary health care team. A community-as-partner assessment and diagnosis project, which culminates in identification of a community health problem and potential solutions, augments core clinical practice. At the beginning of the following fall term, all students are required to present their community projects at a poster session. In addition, students at remote sites will meet with the course coordinator at a time to be announced in the fall of the following semester. This course is graded on a Pass/Fail basis. Required for all students in the prespecialty year
title: Clinical Practice in Community Health Nursing
subject: NURS

description: 2 credit hours. Sessions explore the multidisciplinary theoretical foundations that are the basis for community health nursing practice across the life span. Topics include history of community health nursing and public health science; structure and function of federal, state, and local health organizations; funding mechanisms for community health care; epidemiological and biostatistical indicators of community health; methods of family and community analyses. Required for all students in the prespecialty year.
title: Seminar in Community Health Nursing and Public Health?
subject: NURS

description: This elective study is initiated by the student and negotiated with faculty. The purpose is to allow in-depth pursuit of individual areas of interest and/or practice. A written proposal must be submitted and signed by the student, the faculty member(s), and the appropriate specialty director. Credit varies according to the terms of the contract.
title: Master’s Independent Study
subject: NURS

title: Clinical Practicum for ONPs
subject: NURS

description: 4.3 credit hours. The focus of this practicum is comprehensive management of a caseload of patients with students’ elected special populations (cardiovascular, oncology). Emphasis is on prediction of common patient problems, formulation of management protocols, and generation of research questions. The practice sites in acute, ambulatory, and/or long-term settings provide an opportunity to observe system problems and develop clinical leadership strategies. Required for all clinical nurse specialist students in the final year of specialization. Acute care nurse practitioner students must take 810c during the summer following 612b, unless they can demonstrate experience in caring for critically ill patients managed with complex technological interventions. Prerequisite: successful completion of 612b. Twelve hours of clinical practice plus one hour of clinical conference per week.
title: Advanced Specialty Practicum II?
subject: NURS

title: Primary Care of Children II
subject: NURS

description: Historical and analytical inquiry into the meanings of happiness and their change over time. How new approaches to this topic in the social and natural sciences both complement and challenge time-honored philosophical and religious ideas. Whether happiness is a subjective and/or culturally relative idea. Whether happiness should be a goal in life. The relationship of happiness to other valued goods such as meaning, freedom, pleasure, virtue, and justice. 1 Credit. Tuition $2,750. Session A: May 31 - July 2.
title: Happiness
subject: PHIL

description: An introduction to formal logic. Study of the formal deductive systems and semantics for both propositional and predicate logic. Some discussion of metatheory. 1 Credit. Tuition $2,750. Session A: May 31 - July 2.
title: First-Order Logic
subject: PHIL

description: Introduction to the field of ethics. Topics include the basis of morality, what a person is morally required to do for others, and what makes one act right and another wrong. Attention to theories associated with John Stuart Mill, Immanuel Kant, and Aristotle. Some consideration of how ethical theory can be applied to particular questions in society and in our personal lives. 1 Credit. Tuition $2,750. Session B: July 5 - August 6.
title: Introduction to Ethics
subject: PHIL

description: Introduction to problems and methods in the philosophy of law. The nature of law and legal authority; political questions regarding the nature of rights and limitations on freedom; issues in criminal law, tort law, and contract law. 1 Credit. Tuition $2,750. Session B: July 5 - August 6.
title: Introduction to Philosophy of Law
subject: PHIL

description: Introduction to Eastern philosophy through the study of philosophical and religious texts. Topics include reality and illusion, knowledge, self, right and wrong, nonattachment, meditation, aesthetics, the meaning of life, and death. 1 Credit. Tuition $2,750. Session B: July 5 - August 6.
title: Eastern Philosophy
subject: PHIL

description: Seminar that examines the science behind selected advances in modern technology. Focus on the scientific and contextual basis of each advance, as well as the technology's resulting impact on society. Student groups present case studies, with topics developed by the participants in collaboration with the instructor. Intended for non-science majors. 1 Credit. Tuition: $2750. Session B: July 5 - August 6.
title: Science and Modern Technology
subject: PHYS

description: Seminar which covers the technology, use, and impact of energy on the environment, climate, security, and the economy. Emphasis on what drives people's choices and the effects of those choices. Prerequisite: a background in high school physics, chemistry, and mathematics. 1 Credit. Tuition: $2750. Session A: May 31 - July 2.
title: Energy, Technology and Society
subject: PHYS

description: First part of a broad introduction, including the traditional parts of classical physics as well as selected topics in modern physics. Emphasis on fundamental principles, with examples of practical applications to medicine and other fields. Covers mechanics, thermodynamics, and wave motion. Suitable for students interested in the biological and medical sciences. Intended primarily for college students. Pre-college students with a background in physics and a solid basis in calculus may apply subject to instructor's approval. PHYS 150 and 151 are normally taken in sequence. 1 Credit. Tuition $2,750. Session A: May 31 - July 2.
title: General Physics
subject: PHYS

description: Second part of a broad introduction, including the traditional parts of classical physics as well as selected topics in modern physics.  Emphasis on fundamental principles, with examples of practical applications to medicine and other fields. Covers electricity and magnetism, optics, and modern physics. Suitable for students interested in the biological and medical sciences. Intended primarily for college students. Pre-college students with a background in physics and a solid basis in calculus may apply subject to instructor's approval. Prerequisite: PHYS 150 or equivalent. 1 Credit. Tuition $2,750. Session B: July 5 - August 6.
title: General Physics
subject: PHYS

description: A large variety of laboratory experiments, coordinated with the lecture course PHYS S-150, and designed to illustrate the physical principles developed in the lectures. Intended primarily for college students. Pre-college students with a solid basis in calculus may apply subject to instructor's approval. 1/2 Credit. Tuition $1,375. Session A: May 31 - July 2.
title: Laboratory for General Physics
subject: PHYS

description: A large variety of laboratory experiments, coordinated with the lecture course PHYS S-151, and designed to illustrate the physical principles developed in the lectures. Intended primarily for college students. Pre-college students with a solid basis in calculus may apply subject to instructor's approval. 1/2 Credit. Tuition $1,375. Session B: July 5 - August 6.
title: Laboratory for General Physics
subject: PHYS

description: A broad introduction to classical and modern physics for students who have some previous preparation in physics and mathematics. Covers Newtonian mechanics, gravitation, waves, and thermodynamics. Calculus at the level of MATH 112 is a prerequisite. May be taken concurrently with MATH 115 and 120 or equivalents.  May not be taken for credit after PHYS 150, 151. 1 Credit. Tuition $2,750. Session A: May 31 - July 2.
title: Advanced General Physics
subject: PHYS

description: A broad introduction to classical and modern physics for students who have some previous preparation in physics and mathematics. Covers electromagnetism, optics, special relativity, and quantum physics. Calculus at the level of MATH 112 is a prerequisite. May be taken concurrently with MATH 115 and 120 or equivalents.  May not be taken for credit after PHYS 150, 151. Prerequisite: PHYS 180 or equivalent. 1 Credit. Tuition $2,750. Session B: July 5 - August 6.
title: Advanced General Physics
subject: PHYS

description: Issues of liberty, equality, and justice considered from within the Western tradition of political philocophy. Readings from Plato, Aristotle, Hobbes, Locke, Rousseau, Marx, Mill and contemporary authors. 1 Credit. Tuition $2,750. Session B: July 5 - August 6.
title: Introduction to Political Philosophy
subject: PLSC

title: ConflictCoopinPostcommEurope
subject: PLSC

description: A theoretical approach to themes at the intersection of international relations and comparative politics, with a focus on the relationship between international politics and internal conflict. Topics include secessions and irredentas; links between civil war duration, the durability of peace, and third-party interventions; the spatial diffusion of conflict within and across borders; sovereignty and stability; and management techniques to moderate the occurrence and extent of conflict. 1 Credit. Tuition $2,750. Session A: May 31 - July 2.
title: International Dimensions of Internal Conflict
subject: PLSC

description: American grand strategy since the collapse of the Soviet Union. The ability of the United States to project its power around the world. Constraints on and challenges to American power in the international political system. The effect of nuclear weapons on the workings of a unipolar world. The possible emergence of peer competitors in the future. 1 Credit. Tuition $2,750. Session B: July 5 - August 6.
short_title: U.S. Strategy After the Cold War
title: U.S. Strategy After the Cold War
subject: PLSC

description: International human rights bodies and their implications for international politics. The role of human rights institutions in affording remedies to victims of state abuse. The emergence and exercise of international human rights law, including its nature, mechanisms, and logic. 1 Credit. Tuition: $2750. Session A: May 31 - July 2.
title: International Human Rights and Politics
subject: PLSC

description: A study of the Cold War as an event in international history, surveying its origins, course, conclusions, and legacy from the perspectives of its major participants. Topics include the Cold War's effects on society, culture and intellectual life. In addition to textbooks, students will also read recently declassified, published and translated American, Soviet, East European, Chinese, Korean, and Vietnamese documents. Film screenings will include Dr. Strangelove and Goodbye, Lenin! There will also be a field trip to the Cold War memorabilia and primary sources exhibition at Yale University Archives and an optional outing to a 1950s nuclear fallout shelter site. 1 Credit. Tuition $2,750. Session A: May 31 - July 2.
title: The Cold War
subject: PLSC

description: A broad introduction to the contemporary politics of American cities. Consideration of the contexts of city governments: globalization and economic restructuring, immigration, federal policy shifts, and city-suburban relationships. Attention to the politics of elite and progressive coalitions and alternative political strategies. The last two weeks focus on the policy issues of economic development and bureaucratic reform. 1 Credit. Tuition $2,750. Session A: May 31 - July 2.
title: Urban Politics and Policy
subject: PLSC

description: Topics in the history, theory, and realities of crime and punishment in the contemporary United States. Focus on various theories of criminal process in light of empirical evidence, the politicization of crime, civil rights issues, psychiatry and the law, abortion, and arguments about prison reform. 1 Credit. Tuition $2,750. Session B: July 5 - August 6.
title: Crime and Punishment
subject: PLSC

description: A survey of the historical development of the executive branch of the American national government; an examination of the politics of presidential leadership; and consideration of how the development of the executive branch has affected presidential politics. 1 Credit. Tuition $2,750. Session A: May 31 - July 2.
title: The American Presidency
subject: PLSC

description: Survey of important modern treatments of problems religion poses for secular political philosophy. Focus on enduringly influential texts in the modern Western tradition. Works by Hobbes, Spinoza, Kant, Rawls, Habermas, and Derrida. 1 Credit. Tuition $2,750. Session A: May 31 - July 2.
title: Religion and Political Theory
subject: PLSC

description: Study of civil war using a model of the dynamic processes of conflict, from antecedents through onset to conclusion. Focus on the analysis of a range of historical and contemporary case studies, including Iraq, Vietnam, and Northern Ireland. Some previous study of political science or a related discipline useful but not necessary. 1 Credit. Tuition $2,750. Session A: May 31 - July 2.

description: An overview of politics in the Middle East and North Africa. State formation, the roles of religion and oil in politics, political institutions, economic development, and the prospects for economic and political reform. 1 Credit. Tuition $2,750. Session A: May 31 - July 2.
title: Introduction to Middle East Politics
subject: PLSC

A comprehensive introduction to Brazilian cultural history, including formation, chronological development, and modern self-description. Texts by major authors and figures in Brazilian literary, cultural, and intellectual history. Conducted in English. Prerequisite: PSYC 110 or equivalent. 1 Credit. Tuition $2,750. Session A: May 31 - July 2.

description: Introduction to the religions studied as "Buddhism," "Judaism," "Christianity," and "Afro-Caribbean Religion," with a focus on the interaction between the global representation of these traditions and local lived practice in New Haven. Thematic exploration of gender and sexuality in these traditions. Course work includes on-site visits, Internet research, and class presentations. 1 Credit. Tuition $2,750. Session A: May 31 - July 2.
title: Religion and Globalization
subject: RLST

description: Examination of creation myths and major approaches to their interpretation. Primary texts from Babylon, Greece, the Near East, the Mayans and other cultures. All readings in English. 1 Credit. Tuition $2,750. Session B: July 5 - August 6.
title: Cosmogonic Myths
subject: RLST

description: An introduction to Islam. Topics include Muhammad and the Qur'an; Muslim tradition and religious law; Islamic philosophy and theology; Shi'ism and Sufism; basic beliefs and practices of the Muslim community; religious institutions; and modern trends. 1 Credit. Tuition $2,750. Session A: May 31 - July 2.
title: The Religion of Islam
subject: RLST

description: The Old Testament/Hebrew Bible as an expression of the religious life and thought of ancient Israel and a foundational document of Western civilization. Emphasis on the texts' historical and cultural setting in the ancient Near East. Introduction to a wide range of critical and literary approaches to Biblical study. Close reading of selected passages, with discussion of their history of interpretation. 1 Credit. Tuition $2,750. Session B: July 5 - August 6.
title: Introduction to the Hebrew Bible
subject: RLST

description: History of Arabic-speaking Christians and Christian-Muslim encounters from the rise of Islam to the modern age. Topics include views of Jesus and Christianity in early Islam; initial Christian responses to the Arab conquest; medieval Arabic Christian theology, philosophy, and ethics; the impact of the Crusades; religion and politics in modern Palestine and Egypt; and the experience of Arabic Christians after 9/11. 1 Credit. Tuition $2,750. Session B: July 5 - August 6.
title: Christians and Muslims in the Arab World
subject: RLST

description: The history, beliefs, and practices of the Christian tradition from antiquity to the present. Major themes and figures. The development of the three classical divisions of the movement: Eastern Orthodox, Roman Catholic, and Protestant. Christianity as a worldwide phenomenon, including current global trends. Some attention to the role of Yale in the American Christian tradition. 1 Credit. Tuition $2,750. Session B: July 5 - August 6.
title: Introduction to Christianity
subject: RLST

title: From Crusade to Enlightenment
subject: RLST

description: Second half offered in St. Petersburg, Russia. An intensive "at-home-and-abroad" course featuring language study at either the second- or third-year level of Russian. Students receive language training during the first three weeks in New Haven, developing skills that are then applied during the last five weeks in Russia. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from St. Petersburg, costs of room and board while in Russia, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: April 1. Enrollment limited. Must be taken in conjunction with RUSS S-242. 3 Credits. Tuition $5,700. 8 Weeks: May 31 - July 27.
title: Russian Language
subject: RUSS

description: Second half offered in St. Petersburg, Russia. An interdisciplinary exploration of Russian cultural history through its art, architecture, theater, music, and film. Topics include conceptions of Russian nationhood; myths of St. Petersburg and Moscow; dissent and persecution; elites, intelligentsia, and attitudes toward the common people; conflicting appeals of rationality, spirituality, and idealism; the politicizing of personal life; and effects of Russian artistic innovations worldwide. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from St. Petersburg, costs of room and board, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: April 1. Enrollment limited. Must be taken in conjunction with RUSS S-177. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 Credit. Tuition: see RUSS S177.  8 Weeks: May 31 - July 23.
title: Russian Culture
subject: RUSS

description: Offered in Mumbai, India. Critical introduction to contemporary Indian politics, society, culture, and religion through immersive study in Mumbai. Topics include urbanization, poverty, migration, housing, communal violence, caste segregation, class ghettoization, and popular culture. Must be taken in conjunction with SAST S364. Enrollment limited. Application deadline: April 1. For more information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 Credit. Tuition $2,650. Session A: May 31 - July 2.

subject: SAST

Enrollment limited. Application deadline: April 1. For more information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 Credit. Tuition $2,650. Session A: May 31 - July 2.
title: A Linguistic History of India
subject: SAST

description: This course is intended to provide comprehensive training and support to STARS students engaged in scientific research. Students will be introduced to the scientific process, including hypothesis testing, experimental design and data interpretation, through lectures, reading and discussions of the primary scientific literature. Skills development will emphasize the process of discussions of preparing written scientific reports and oral presentations highlighting effectual communication skills and the ability to interpret and display quantitative and qualitative informations. For STARS students only. Course may not be repeated for credit. 1 credit. Tuition: $2750. June 7 - August 6.
title: Scientific Research: Process and Presentation
subject: SCIE

description: Major works of social thought that articulate the core ideas of sociology. Attention to social and historical contexts, conceptual frameworks and methods, and contributions to contemporary social analysis. Writers include Hobbes, Locke, J.S. Mill, Rousseau, Marx, Durkheim, and Weber. 1 Credit. Tuition $2,750. Session B: July 5 - August 6.
title: Foundations of Modern Social Theory
subject: SOCY

description: Introduction to public health issues and health development processes that are independent of national territorial boundaries but also incorporate the health needs and priorities of individual nation states. Mechanisms and challenges involved in incorporating the World Health Organization's commitment to primary health care with principles that currently dominate the global public health agenda. Sociological critique of public health interventions. 1 Credit. Tuition: $2,750. Session B: July 5 - August 6.
title: Global Public Health
subject: SOCY

description: Responses by law enforcement and the wider criminal justice system to political and moral imperatives advanced under the banner of diversity and multiculturalism. Contemporary social issues such as racial profiling, disproportionate punishment, unequal justice, and terrorism. 1 Credit. Tuition: $2,750. Session B: July 5 - August 6.

description: Social movement and network theory used to analyze the emergence and evolution of Islamic movements from the early twentieth century to the present. Organization, mobilization, and framing of political, nonpolitical, militant, and nonmilitant movements; transnational dimensions of Islamic activism. Case studies include the Muslim Brotherhood, Hamas, Hizbollah, Al-Qaeda, Al-Adl wa-Ihsann, and Tablighi Jama'at. 1 Credit. Tuition $2,750. Session A: May 31 - July 2.
title: Islamic Social Movements
subject: SOCY

description: Offered in Dubrovnik, Croatia. Multidisciplinary study of southeastern Europe from antiquity to modernity. Byzantine presence and the remnants of the Roman world; consequences of the schism between Rome and Constantinople; barbarian kingdoms and the medieval city-states; Ottoman incursions and millets; Renaissance and Baroque; beginning of nationalism and modern national integrations; national revolutions, fascism, communism, and postcommunist conflicts; secularization of religion; genocide in post-Yugoslav wars. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Dubrovnik, room and board costs in Croatia, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Must be taken in conjucntion with HIST S299. description: This course examines the ways in which applied theater has been used to foster civic participation and to address social concerns such as racism, poverty, gender-based violence, access to health care, and education. 1 Credit. Tuition $2750. Session B: July 5 - August 6.
title: Applied Theater, Trauma, Cultural Intervention
subject: THST

description: Offered in New Haven; Mbabane, Swaziland; and Durban, South Africa. This interdisciplinary course introduces students to major issues of the HIV/AIDS pandemic in southern Africa through the perspective of community-engaged theatrical practice. Students will actively engage ideas encountered in our first week of intensive classroom work, held in New Haven, through theater workshops with local artists in Mbabane, Swaziland and Cape Town, South Africa. Two-week collaborations with theater companies in Swaziland and South Africa will amplify and deepen our classroom study of theater as a mode of social and political intervention and of major topics on the HIV/AIDS pandemic. Through experiences in the classroom and in the field, students will arrive at deeply informed perspectives on the AIDS pandemic in southern Africa and will gain an activated understanding of the issues in public health, as well as the possibilities for theatrical interventions. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Swaziland and South Africa, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: March 1. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summer session: abroad@yale.edu. 2 Credits. Tuition $5,300. Course dates: May 31 - July 9.
